>> um yes so uh the question is about how
if you've got any kind of general tips
or whatnot for how you make really
complex ideas understandable to uh
somebody without that kind of background
in that area of journalism. So, somebody

>> Sure. Yeah. I think the first thing is
don't try and communicate the whole
story. If the whole story is complex,
you can't boil it down without losing
important detail. What you're better off
doing is focusing on one area of the
story. And um with research, it's good
to think about who the audience is. Who
cares about the research? So if you've
discovered an amazing new material you
can make a football from, then you want
to go to football players or people who
watch football and tell them why this
new material is amazing, why it affects
their life, why they would care about
it. So if you start from an audience
point of view and don't you don't have
to explain to them how the new material
is made, what it's made of, you can just
start with one point about it that
really helps them. And I think looking
at the science communication that's
happened throughout the pandemic, we've
seen a lot of people like their trust in
news media has been eroded because
journalists have too often tried to give
us all of the data and all of the
information but boil it down into 25
words or less. And they've lost a lot of
nuance and important detail that people
then sort of feel like they're getting
the wool pulled over their eyes or they
don't have enough information to make
their own decisions. they feel like
they're not being trusted with the full
story by the journalists. So, you don't
want your audiences in that position.
You'd be better off just giving them a
little portion of the story that is
accurate um but is also simple and able
to be communicated succinctly.

networking, um the approach is called
informational interviewing. Now, in
informationational interviewing, what it
means is saying to someone, hey, I'm
really interested in what you're doing.
Would you prepare be prepared to give me
20 minutes of your time to have a bit of
a chat about about that? And it's a fair
it's a really non-threatening approach

really important thing for you to do now
